d66062da-cc4e-418a-aca6-fbddd5125033.description: This individual has completed the Advanced Technical Writing for the Manufacturing Industry course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This programme is run in partnership with Innopharma Education, leaders in High-Tech manufacturing education and training. Aiming to establish high standards of technical writing in manufacturing, this course provides practical guidance on style and language to develop high quality, factual and succinct documentation.
d66062da-cc4e-418a-aca6-fbddd5125033.name: Advanced Technical Writing for the Manufacturing Sector

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can demonstrate the required skills to ensure documents are structured, compliant and presented in a consistent manner.
The individual can understand their target audience and identify the regulatory expectations for technical writing and documentation.
The individual can demonstrate the ability to ensure information documented presents a logical flow and is chronologically organised.
The individual can demonstrate a consistent approach to how documents and reports are structured.
The individual can demonstrate an ability to write with focus and present information in a clear and concise manner.
The individual can demonstrate an ability to understand the importance of fact checking and CAPA status.

skills.name: CAPA, root cause analysis and investigations
Document guides and document templates, the importance of standardisation

d3897792-bd87-4491-927d-bbea277ddbdf.description: This individual has successfully completed the Pyramid of Automation Technologies course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with SMC, the world’s leading expert, supporting automation through the most advanced pneumatic and electric technologies. The course introduced the learner to the field of automation and expands their skills and understanding of the technologies that form the industrial automation pyramid.
d3897792-bd87-4491-927d-bbea277ddbdf.name: Industry 4.0 Automation Pyramid Technologies

badge_template_activities.title: The individual understands the relationship between components in industrial automation and has expanded their knowledge on the importance, benefits and energy sources involved in these systems exploring a specific assembly process to understand generic automated systems.

The individual understands the basic principles, laws and components used in pneumatic / electropneumatic systems, the types, operating principles and symbols for the different components used in industrial applications.

The individual understands the production, transport, distribution and use of electricity, components and control circuits and is familiar with different types of circuits and electrical applications, capable of understanding laws and relationships between electrical parameters. Completed theory of direct (DC) and alternating current (AC) with focus on the most common DC circuits (series, parallel) to AC, Induction and electromagnetism, understanding how circuits work and their applications.

The individual understands the components, tools and procedures used in connecting and wiring control panels and electrical facilities. Understands earthing, connectors, cable sizes and the different ways of connecting transformers.

The individual understands the operating principles for basic electrical machines such as direct current and alternate current motors, both single phase and three phase and the most typical applications for these motors.

The individual understands the operating principles of sensors and transducers used in industry. Starting with general applications, features and parameters of sensors, the different types of sensors, their application and symbols.

The individual understands the different types of Programmable Controllers (PLC), centred on the elements of PLC’s, introducing digital electronics and understands how a Programmable Controller works. Studies included its general structure, the PSU, CPU, Input/Outputs and general concepts of programming and applications for these controllers.

The individual understands Process Control systems. The different control types were analysed, focused on the different blocks making up a closed loop controller and introduction to multi-variable control systems.

The individual understands hydraulic systems used in automated industry. Covering the different components used in hydraulics, electro-hydraulics and proportional hydraulics, analysing their operating principles, applied physical laws and symbols.

The individual understands robotic systems and the most common tasks of Industrial Robots. Has the ability to distinguish between the different types of Industrial Robots and understands the history of Industrial Robots. Has explored, in greater depth, these systems’ security aspects, robot structure, programming and the most common industrial applications.

7f9bd131-6e6d-4a5a-b995-99db80e17985.description: This individual has successfully completed the Introduction to QC for (Bio) Pharmaceutical Manufacturing course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with Innopharma Education, leaders in High-Tech manufacturing education and training, and aims to provide learners with an understanding of the role of quality control within an organization and how it relates to the manufacture of pharmaceutical products.
7f9bd131-6e6d-4a5a-b995-99db80e17985.name: Introduction to QC for (Bio) Pharmaceutical Manufacturing

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can describe the relationship between QC and QA.
The individual demonstrated an understanding of an organisations regulatory requirements related to QC.
The individual can demonstrate the ability to communicate complex and technical information in a succinct, effective and professional manner.
The individual can identify the key components of SOPs related to QC documentation.
The individual can describe the principles of validation in relation to QC.

skills.name: GMP Compliance for Healthcare Products and Pharmaceuticals
QC Test methods and Procedures, Accuracy, Precision and Reliability

3d6b942e-4a2e-40f1-a3fb-8334084552a3.description: This individual has participated in the Introduction to Robotics (Entry level) workshop delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This workshop is run in partnership with KUKA, a leading specialist in Automation. This workshop introduced the learner to robotics, as well as the industries and applications in which they are deployed. The participant has been shown the key components of a robot cell and has executed jogging and basic motion programming tasks.
3d6b942e-4a2e-40f1-a3fb-8334084552a3.name: Introduction to Robotics (Entry Level)

badge_template_activities.title: This individual has been given an overview of industrial robots and their evolution through to present day.
This individual is aware of different applications and industries that robotics and automation are commonly utilized.
This individual understands the benefits of using robotics and how they can help a company.
This individual can identify the different components commonly found in an industrial robotic cell.
This individual has been given hands on time with a robot, and has jogged the robot in different coordinate systems.
This individual has created a basic robot program using inline forms on the teach pendant.

c29bba99-f108-49e6-98bc-39fbc43ebcca.description: This individual has successfully completed the Introduction to cGMP for the (Bio)Pharmaceutical Industry course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This programme is run in partnership with Innopharma Education, leaders in High-Tech manufacturing education and training, and aims to provide knowledge of working in a cGMP, regulated (bio)pharmaceutical manufacturing environment.
c29bba99-f108-49e6-98bc-39fbc43ebcca.name: Introduction to cGMP for the (Bio) Pharmaceutical Industry

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can understand terminology associated with cGMP and the regulatory requirements of working in this environment.
The individual can demonstrate an understanding of basic principles associated with validation within a (bio)pharmaceutical context.
The individual developed an understanding of the essential facts related to relevant legal, quality, and regulatory frameworks governing the manufacture of (bio)pharmaceutical products.
The individual demonstrates an understanding of the technologies associated with the production of (bio) pharmaceutical and chemical synthesis products.

skills.name: The fundamentals of validation in a cGMP environment

491df52b-24d5-43f3-b8c8-1a1f648cef76.description: This individual has successfully completed the Introduction to Validation for the Pharmaceutical Industry course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with Innopharma Education, leaders in High-Tech manufacturing education and training and aims to assist learners to understand the regulatory requirements related to validation practices and documentation to ensure consistent high-quality pharmaceutical products.
491df52b-24d5-43f3-b8c8-1a1f648cef76.name: Introduction to Validation for the Pharmaceutical Industry

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can understand and describe the validation lifecycle.
The individual can demonstrate knowledge and competence related to the V model for equipment qualification.
The individual can demonstrate an awareness of regulatory responsibility of a manufacturing organization in relation to validation.
The individual can understand the CAPA process with regard to validation studies.

skills.name: Installation qualification, operational qualification, performance qualification (IQ,OQ PQ)
Lifecycle approach to drug development processes and validation

3128f36e-1b74-4e86-b4b1-c4bb0dae7536.description: This individual has successfully completed the Introduction to PLCs course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with TECHNOTRAINING Ireland’s leading provider of training for engineers, maintenance technicians, and contractors who want to develop their technical skills and qualifications. The course will provide learners with a strong understanding of how PLCs act as the hub in an automated process.
3128f36e-1b74-4e86-b4b1-c4bb0dae7536.name: Introduction to Programmable Logic Controllers

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can understand the architecture of a PLC.
The individual can understand PLC Wiring.
The individual can understand PLC data types.
The individual can create short PLC programmes.
The individual can troubleshoot PLC systems using software.

5896b952-f166-4476-bddd-1bcdc02ff300.description: This individual has successfully completed the Advanced Level Robotics program, delivered by the AMTCE, and run in partnership with KUKA, a world leader in Automation. This program provides essential information about robot programming and executing Expert level tasks using variables, arrays, structures, and programming a KUKA robot with KUKA Robot Language. In practical modules the learner has applied knowledge and created complex robot programs such as a multidimensional palletizing routine.
5896b952-f166-4476-bddd-1bcdc02ff300.name: Introduction to Robotics (Advanced Level)

badge_template_activities.title: This individual is able to carry out expert level tasks and program in long hand KUKA Robot Language (KRL). This includes utilising user defined variables, arrays and structures, and incorporating the use of control functions such as loops, conditional statements and switch statements into their programs.
This individual can apply their knowledge to create more complex robot programs such as multi-dimensional palletizing and depalletizing routines.
This individual has knowledge in cycle time optimization and dialog messaging.
This individual has created and executed programs using digital inputs, digital outputs and synchronized outputs (SYN-OUT).
This individual understands the mastering principle, and can demonstrate how to calibrate and use different tool and base coordinate systems in conjunction with the robot.

68e82e34-5e23-41de-b6c2-6f8d7f8255b2.description: This individual has successfully completed the Industrial Electrical Systems course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with TECHNOTRAINING, Ireland’s leading provider of training for engineers, technicians, and contractors. The course develops the skills required by industrial maintenance technicians to safely diagnose and repair faults in electrically controlled equipment.
68e82e34-5e23-41de-b6c2-6f8d7f8255b2.name: Industrial Electrical Systems

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can test electrical systems to narrow down a problem area.
The individual can list electrical hazards when testing live systems and identify ways to minimise hazards.
The individual can use electrical schematics to navigate a system effectively.
The individual can set-up and troubleshoot a range of sensors used in automation systems.
The individual can carry out LOTO procedures correctly.
The individual can describe the operating principles of fuses, MCBs, and RCDs.
The individual can use multi-meters and grip-ons to test systems in a competent manner.
The individual can test 3 phase motor circuits controlled by contractors and overloads.
The individual can test and fault find electrical actuators including 3-phase motors, solenoids and coils, DC motors.
The individual can follow a structured method for fault finding in a PLC controlled system.
The individual can demonstrate how to troubleshoot a range of common faults in commercial electrical systems.

15912526-dd8b-48e8-b72f-ad27fdbc4ca3.description: This individual has successfully completed the Intermediate Level Robotics program delivered by the AMTCE, and run in partnership with KUKA, a world leader in Automation. The individual has gained knowledge about the structure of a robot system, necessary start up and commissioning procedures, and how to operate a robot cell compliant with robot safety regulations. Learners are introduced to different coordinate systems used in robotics and create their own programs using inline forms.
15912526-dd8b-48e8-b72f-ad27fdbc4ca3.name: Introduction to Robotics (Intermediate Level)

badge_template_activities.title: This individual knows the necessary start up and commissioning procedures such as mastering, calculating load data and calibrating tool and base coordinate systems.
This individual knows how to operate a robot cell compliant with robot safety regulations.
This individual knows how to start and execute robot programs manually and in automatic mode.
This individual has developed their motion programming skills through the creation of robot tasks and has demonstrated the ability to use technology packages such as gripperTech.
This individual can combine pick and place operations into their motion programs and incorporate more advanced topics such as triggers, control functions and sub program calls.

b2f37f88-cd7a-4794-b829-3e0cb35cb742.description: This individual has successfully completed the Introduction to Technical Writing for the Manufacturing Sector course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with Innopharma Education, leaders in High-Tech manufacturing education and training, and aims to provide learners with the tools to write better technical documents, focusing on skills needed to produce accurate succinct documentation within a manufacturing setting.
b2f37f88-cd7a-4794-b829-3e0cb35cb742.name: Introduction to Technical Writing for the Manufacturing Sector

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can understand their target audience and identify the audience expectations for technical writing and documentation.
The individual has demonstrated the required skills to ensure documents are structured, compliant, and presented in a consistent manner.
The individual can recognise and apply the common features of all standard report structures.
The individual has demonstrated the ability to communicate complex and technical information in a succinct, effective, and professional manner.

skills.name: Principles and Techniques for Technical Writing
Writing methods, Writing with focus, Presenting information concisely

6b5e4652-ff9f-404a-a5a1-36c262a1e464.description: This individual has successfully completed the Programmable Logic Controllers course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with TECHNOTRAINING, Ireland’s leading provider of training for engineers, technicians, and contractors. The course will enable maintenance staff to interrogate PLC code to determine the cause of machine faults and hang-ups.
6b5e4652-ff9f-404a-a5a1-36c262a1e464.name: Programmable Logic Controllers

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can Navigate RSLogix 500 competently
The individual can set-up an Ethernet Interface to Communicate with a MicroLogix PLC and assign an IP address to the PLC using BOOT-TP
The individual can compare Offline files to those in PLC memory and understand the way RSLogix 500 organizes Ladder Files
The individual can Create PLC Data Files and define data types
The individual can Interrogate Basic Ladder Logic Instructions
The individual can use watch tables.
The individual can use the Cross-Referencing tool to navigate code.
The individual can track and control sequences with the MOV instruction (found commonly in Industry).
The individual can troubleshoot a robot Pick and Place sequence with simulated faults in Factory IO.

3166d429-3bd4-4358-93a5-63fe54af99d2.description: This individual has successfully completed the Robotic Welding program, delivered by the AMTCE, and run in partnership with KUKA, a world leader in Automation. Learners have demonstrated the ability to perform complex motion programming, and follow correct program structure required for weld routines. The individual has configured weld parameters on the robot and the Fronius power source, and created robot programs using the ArcTech option package to perform various welds and weave patterns.
3166d429-3bd4-4358-93a5-63fe54af99d2.name: Robotic Welding

badge_template_activities.title: This individual has been given an introduction to robotic welding and an overview of applications and industries where robotic welding is used.
This individual can safely work with an industrial robotic welding cell.
This individual can start and execute programs manually and in automatic mode.
This individual has demonstrated the ability to perform complex motion programming required for welding paths, and understands setting the torch angle/working position with the robot.
This individual has configured welding parameters via the robot teach pendant and the Fronius welding power source.

f54cd23b-f198-4a02-920f-1fae88632fb9.description: This individual has successfully completed the Digital Sensors course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with TECHNOTRAINING, a leading provider of training for engineers, technicians, and contractors who want to develop their technical skills and qualifications. The course enables learners to install, set up and fault find a comprehensive range of digital sensors wired to a PLC through digital input interfaces.
f54cd23b-f198-4a02-920f-1fae88632fb9.name: Digital Sensors

badge_template_activities.title: The individual will be capable of wiring NPN, PNP and 2 wire-sensors to PLC input cards.
The individual can understand sensing principles including, inductive, capacitive, thru beam, fibre optic, diffuse, retro reflective sensors.
The individual can follow a logical procedure for adjusting the sensitively for robust stable sensing for the listed sensors.
The individual will be capable of interpreting the meaning of the two indicating LED’s when fault finding.
The individual can understand how to setup optical sensors for LO or DO operation.
The individual will appreciate the setup required for digital pressure/vacuum switches for window and switching.

f268a456-bacf-45ff-a089-4f5201ff2d6a.description: This individual has successfully completed the Electrical Safety Awareness course delivered by the Advanced Manufacturing Training Centre of Excellence (AMTCE). This program is run in partnership with TECHNO TRAINING, Ireland’s leading provider of training for engineers, maintenance technicians, and contractors. This comprehensive course will heighten awareness of electrical hazards and provide a set of safe working practise and precautions that address risks for those working around LV systems.
f268a456-bacf-45ff-a089-4f5201ff2d6a.name: Electrical Safety Awareness

badge_template_activities.title: The individual can explain the effects of electricity on the human body and describe the four Shock Factors.
The individual can evaluate the cause-and-effect relationship between voltage, current and resistance in series and parallel circuits.
The individual can use a multi-meter to measure voltage.
The individual can recognise and explain the types of Circuit Protection devices to include fuses, MCB’s and RCD’s and RCBO’s.
The individual can explain all the engineering controls in place to protect against contact with LIVE conductors.
The individual can competently and safely measure voltage in LIVE electrical circuits powered with DC and AC (single and 3-phase).
The individual can list all the procedural measures that should be taken to reduce risk of exposure to electrical hazards such as shock and Arc flash hazards.
The individual can perform risk assessments before opening Panels.
The individual can isolate power and verify that power is isolated.
The individual can explain how a range of real recorded accidents could have been avoided.
The individual can explain earthing systems to include TN_C and TN_S systems.
The individual can evaluate why and when LOTO is required.
The individual can understand employer and employee responsibilities under the Safety Health and Welfare at Work Act 2005, Clause 86.

skills.name: Safety Health and Welfare at Work Act 2005
